content:
I don't get how in the Ten sides test case, "175 60" is a "hit" in the convex.
I mean, from points "150 25", and "200 75", we should see that "175 50" is the boundary right?

I remove tabs in Input in Ten sides test case and validator 5.
To prevent Integer parsing error in some languages.

This puzzle was so easy that no one did see that Test 5 was incorrect (not convex). :@

That being said, I have:
- fixed Test 5,
- removed a typo,
- rephrased the last sentence,
- changed the tags according to the comments below.
Nicely done. I would rather categorize it as "easy" though.  This is nowhere as complex as some puzzles you can find on "medium" level.

Interesting. But I do not see any interesting in having many shots. You would just add a loop to process each shot one after another.

The difficulty of the puzzle is the same with only one shot.

Also, I suppose it may be solved with a ray-casting algorithm :

https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/how-to-check-if-a-given-point-lies-inside-a-polygon/

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/217578/how-can-i-determine-whether-a-2d-point-is-within-a-polygon

I love this problem. The sentecing is great. With you giving the vertices in some order (clockwise or counter-clockwise), there is a really easy solution. Besides the intialization and output, I wrote it in 2 lines. But again, I love your proposal.

Interesting solution, I implemented the dot product version. All dot products between a line connecting a shot and the centre of a polygon line and a normal to that line must be > 0.

I added more shots just to be sure the implemented solution is a general one. And yes, one should just make a loop and process each shot individually.
I agree I set the difficulty to easy.
Thank you for the updates and error correction.

I submit my answer with 80% test pass and get 100% validation anyway.
I think there is something wrong with the Ten sides test case.
Oops sorry. My test program worked on all cases, I just didn't pay attention to that.

I disagree. All of the easz puzzles could be done with nothing more then brute-force solutions, and are straightforward. In most of the description the solution is explicitly given in terms of human words. This one is far from being easy for most people. I think easy means, that someone who has no previous background knowledge of math or programming can solve it.

If it stays easy, please add "dot product" to tags, because - honestly - geometry doesn't help you to find ideas.

Well you can easily find problems requiring university maths level in "medium", like this crazy puzzle about using big integers to decompose a integer into a sum of Fibonacci numbers, or pretty complex branch and bound problems.

In comparison, this can be solved in a few lines of code provided you know what a dot or cross product is. If you don't then you won't get far in 3D image processing, even at beginner's level.
I would be ok for "medium" if you had to sort the points yourself, for instance.

I agree adding some tags to give an hint at the kind of problem this puzzle relates to would be nice though.

Both have valid points. In my opinion from the viewpoint of computer science, the problem is easy, since it does not require implementation of a complicated algorithm. However, if you want to find the solution yourself, it might take quite a bit of thinking. But, if you google it, you get the idea for the solution quickly. 

Thus, I left it as easy and added "dot product" to tags. Also, I added "particle tracking", which is where the idea for this problem originally came from. In particle tracking in fluid flows algorithms, one needs to find a mesh element in which the particle is located quickly.

That's okay, it can stay easy, it's not a problem for me, I was just suggesting medium, I think something went wrong on saving the new tags, as they don't show.

This debate reminds me of something I read a while ago about software development:
"CEO: Why do we pay $100k a year for software developers, since all they do is copy-paste code from StackOverflow.
Sofware developer: You are perfectly right. Copy-pasting a code costs $1 only, to KNOW which code to copy from a million, that's what you have to pay $100k."

I see the old joke got adapted to StackOverflow now :)
Agreed, all this is highly debatable and defining a difficulty is not an exact science.

Anyway, seems good to go to me.
